name: gzip
desc: gzip is a command-line compression tool on Linux, which can compress files and store them as gzip format files. Using gzip command can greatly reduce the size of files, save disk space, and speed up file transfer.

-c.name: write compressed data to standard output

-l.name: list the information of compressed files

-n.name: specify the size of compressed data block

-t.name: test the integrity of compressed files

-v.name: display detailed information of compression and decompression

-1.name: use the fastest compression speed and the lowest compression ratio

-9.name: use the slowest compression speed and the highest compression ratio

--fast.name: use the fastest compression speed and the lowest compression ratio

--best.name: use the slowest compression speed and the highest compression ratio

content:
Examples

  • Compress a file:

    gzip <file>

  • Compress a directory and all its files:

    gzip -r <dir>

  • Decompress a file:

    gzip -d <file.gz>

  • Write compressed data to standard output:

    gzip -c <file>

  • List the information of compressed files:

    gzip -l <file.gz>
